elements.title: market hall of Niort (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the market hall of Niort (pictured) opened in 1871 and has been listed as a historic monument since 1987?

elements.title: Thomas Lord Kimball (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Kimball County, Nebraska, was named after railroad executive Thomas Lord Kimball?

elements.title: Amazonas de Yaxunah (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Amazonas de Yaxunah, a Mayan softball team from Yucatán, play barefoot while wearing the huipil, a traditional indigenous dress?

elements.title: Hans Steinbrenner (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in 2023, a sculpture garden in Praunheim displayed abstract works by Hans Steinbrenner from different periods of his life, and corresponding works by his friends and students?

elements.title: black borders on letters and envelopes (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that people in the Victorian era commonly placed black borders on letters and envelopes to signify that they were in mourning?

elements.title: humpbacked limia (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in aquariums, the humpbacked limia is known to cannibalise the young?

elements.title: John Buck Wilkin (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that John Buck Wilkin was inspired to write "GTO" during a physics class?

elements.title: Hypericum perforatum (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Hypericum perforatum was a common component of classical cure-all concoctions called theriacs?
